summary: This is an email chain from December 2020 discussing the approval process for a new client seeking therapy as a confirmed victim of Jeffrey Epstein. The correspondence involves FBI Victim Services Division personnel and a licensed psychotherapist, focusing on confirming victim status and authorizing treatment.

persons.name: M.S.
persons.context: A licensed psychotherapist certified in sexual abuse trauma who reached out to inform that a new client is seeking therapy for victimization by Jeffrey Epstein, with treatment scheduled to begin.

events.title: Scheduled therapy session for Epstein victim
events.description: A therapy session is scheduled to begin for a client seeking treatment regarding victimization by Jeffrey Epstein.

locations.name: Greenacres, Florida 33463
locations.context: Location of the licensed psychotherapist's practice.

keyFacts: An email chain from December 2020 shows internal FBI Victim Services Division discussions about approving therapy for a new client claiming to be a victim of Jeffrey Epstein.

The correspondence highlights a procedural requirement to confirm an individual's status as a 'confirmed victim' before authorizing and funding treatment through the FEVAF (possibly the FBI's Victim Assistance Fund).
A licensed psychotherapist from Greenacres, Florida, notified the FBI that she would begin treating the client for sexual abuse trauma related to Epstein on December 8, 2020.
FBI personnel express a need to understand why the victim is starting counseling now and what other counseling options have been explored, indicating a review process for victim services.
The document is an example of post-conviction victim assistance processes within the FBI related to the Epstein case.
